title-group.article-title: Will switching to LED outdoor lighting increase sky glow?

article-meta.aff: Lighting Research Center, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, New York, USA

abstract.p: As LED sources are increasingly being used for outdoor lighting, concerns are being raised about their impact on man-made sky glow. This paper compares the amount of light scattered back to Earth from a 6500 K phosphor-converted white LED light source to that from a 2050 K high pressure sodium (HPS) light source. Calculations based solely on molecular Rayleigh scattering provide an upper limit of 22% more scatter from the LED source, but are not realistic because the atmosphere has significant scatter from aerosol content. Adding in the effects of aerosols in the atmosphere, as derived from aerosol optical depth measurements and Mie scattering distributions, reduces the wavelength dependency of scattered light to where the LED source has roughly 10–20% more scattered light contributing to sky glow. Scattering ratios (LED:HPS) are calculated for different angles and atmospheric conditions.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Recent news articles, papers1 and statements by the International Dark-Sky Association2,3 have warned about the deleterious effects of using light emitting diodes (LEDs) for outdoor lighting. These purported deleterious effects fall into two categories: (1) degrading the appearance, study, and detection of stars and other celestial bodies due to sky glow, including a general reduction of the aesthetic quality of the night, and (2) the non-visual effects of light on the circadian rhythms and melatonin production of people and wildlife exposed to increased light at night.4–6 The arguments against LEDs are based on the spectral composition of their output in comparison to the currently most common type of outdoor lighting source, high pressure sodium (HPS). Specifically, present-day high efficacy LEDs used for outdoor lighting emit much more short wavelength light (λ < 500 nm) than HPS sources for the same total light output and are consequently perceived as whiter light sources; that is, they are more similar to daylight in appearance compared to the yellowish-orange hue of HPS. The concern over the short wavelength content of lighting is exemplified by sentiments such as ‘…with the current trend toward white LEDs which emit a huge amount of blue light, we will enter a period of elevated negative effects of light at night on human health and environment’7 and ‘Unfortunately, bluish light produces high levels of light pollution with significant environmental impact.3

This paper examines one aspect of the argument against the use of high correlated color temperature (CCT) light sources, which is that they disproportionally increase sky glow due to atmospheric scattering. Atmospheric scattering from a LED spectrum is quantitatively compared to scatter from a HPS spectrum for different atmospheric conditions. Comparisons range from a simple worst-case condition having the greatest wavelength dependency, to more realistic conditions where scatter is less dependent on the wavelength of light. Contrary to the implications that LEDs produce much more scattered light, this analysis shows that the effective scattering difference is quite small, about 20% at most. By making use of the technological advantages of LED outdoor lighting, which include better optical control and more power management options such as dimming control and instant turn-on, switching to LED systems could potentially lead to an overall reduction of sky glow.

sec.title: 2. Approach
sec.p:
Scattering of light in the Earth’s atmosphere is categorised into two regimes: Rayleigh scattering for particle sizes much smaller that the wavelength of light (mainly molecules of nitrogen and oxygen) and Mie scattering for larger particle sizes (aerosols of water, dust, salt, etc.). Mie theory converges to the Rayleigh equation as particle size becomes very small. As the particle size approaches and exceeds the wavelength of light, scattering becomes less wavelength-dependent, so pure Rayleigh scattering produces the most wavelength-dependent effects. Unlike Rayleigh scattering, which is described by a relatively simple equation, the equations for Mie scattering are complex and cannot be expressed in a simple analytical form.8 The Mie equations can only be solved numerically, which is a likely explanation for why the relatively large wavelength dependency of Rayleigh scattering is often solely used as evidence supporting the disproportional contribution of scatter by short visible wavelengths. In reality, measurements of atmospheric extinction show that for many locations and times, molecular scattering described by Rayleigh’s equation represents less than half the scattering occurring in the atmosphere.9 Figure 1 shows how the two categories of scatter contribute to sky glow by redirecting upward light back towards the ground. Figure 1
Schematic representation of Rayleigh scattering from air molecules and Mie scattering from larger aerosol particles. The lines and arrows depict the spatial scattering distributions for different skyward emission angles of light from the outdoor fixture

For first-order accuracy and simplicity, the following analysis divides atmospheric scatter into the two regimes of wavelength-dependent Rayleigh for small particles and less wavelength-dependent Mie for particles larger than roughly 0.3 µm. With pure Rayleigh scattering being the worst-case scenario for the argument that sources having relatively more power at short wavelengths have more scatter, changing the proportion of aerosol to molecular scatter (large versus small particle size) allows scatter estimates to be made for different atmospheric conditions and for light emitted up into the sky at different elevation angles. To address the huge range of different atmospheric conditions found at any given time in different places, conditions were summarised by comparing clear sky conditions for two locations: Alberta, Canada, representing a fairly dry continental climate, and coastal Ireland, representing a wetter, marine environment. For each location, measurements of the aerosol optical depth of the atmosphere were used as estimates of the large particle scattering contribution.

sec.title: 3. Small particle Rayleigh scattering
sec.p: Rayleigh scattering is described by the following equation, adapted from the Lord Rayleigh’s original work,8 for the intensity, I(θ), of light scattered from an unpolarised beam of intensity I0, wavelength λ, at a distance r: (1)I(θ)I0=π2υ2m(1+cos2θ)(n2-1)2r2λ4 where υ is the volume of the particle, n is its index of refraction, m is the number of scattering particles and θ is the scattering angle. When comparing the relative amounts of scatter from two spectrally different sources under identical conditions, all of the terms except I0 and λ remain the same and so can be replaced with a single constant k. The angle dependency is not wavelength dependent, so it can be included in the constant k. (2)I(λ)I0(λ)=kλ4 (3)I(λ)=I0(λ)kλ4
The total light scattered is calculated by integrating the intensity spectrum over wavelength. Because k is not wavelength dependent, it can be taken out of the integral. (4)I=k∫I0(λ)λ4dλ

Finally, comparison of two different spectral power distributions can be done by taking the ratio of their integrated intensities (I1/I2). The unknown constant k divides out, leaving an expression that depends only on the spectral power distribution and wavelength. (5)I1I2=∫I1 0(λ)λ4dλ∫I2 0(λ)λ4dλ

In addition to comparing the radiant intensity, comparison of the photometric intensity (L) can be made by weighting each integral by the photopic luminous efficiency function, V(λ). Comparisons can be done using other spectral weighting functions as well. (6)L1L2=∫I1 0(λ)V(λ)λ4dλ∫I2 0(λ)V(λ)λ4dλ

This last equation can be used to calculate a worst-case scenario for the change in atmospheric scatter when changing light source spectra. For example, switching from a HPS source to a 6500 K phosphor-converted (PC) white LED source (Figure 2) results in a LLED/LHPS ratio of 1.22. Relating this to lighting practice, assuming the same light distribution, the same horizontal illuminance, and the same amount of spectrally flat ground reflection from these two sources, the LED source would result in 22% more sky glow than the HPS source. This worst-case scenario is for an atmosphere free of any particles larger than gas molecules, that is, no dust, water vapour, smog, etc. Adding in these other larger particle atmospheric constituents will only decrease this difference in scatter between these two light sources. Figure 2
Spectral power distributions for a phosphor-converted (PC) white LED with a correlated colour temperature of 6500 K (dashed line) and a 400 W high pressure sodium (HPS) lamp (solid line). Both spectra are scaled for 1 lumen of photometric output

In other words, while more realistic atmospheric conditions having significant amounts of aerosol scatter may produce a lot more scatter for both light sources, the ratio of scatter between these two spectra will always be less than 1.22.

sec.title: 4. Large particle Mie scattering
sec.p: Large particle scattering as described by Mie scattering theory does not have a simple analytical equation as small particle Rayleigh scattering does, so a different approach needs to be taken to compare the amount of scattering for spectrally different sources when including aerosols. The situation is further complicated by particle size being an important parameter for determining both the direction and amount of scatter.

Detailed measurements and analyses of the atmospheric optical depth (OD) of Rayleigh scattering have been done, from which empirical formulae have been developed.10,11 The equations take the form OD = kλ−n, where k is approximately 0.0087 and the exponent n is approximately 4.0, in agreement with the Rayleigh scattering formula (Equation (1)). The optical depth describes how much of the transmitted light is unaffected by the scattering medium; therefore, 1–e−OD is the proportion of scattered light. Within the visible spectrum, these formulae are accurate to within a few percent.10 The distribution of scattered light in the Rayleigh regime is symmetrical and fixed (the 1 + cos2θ factor in Equation (1)), so the amount of light scattered into any hemisphere is always 50%.

Measurements of the total atmospheric optical depth are available for many different locations on Earth. The optical depth of the atmospheric aerosols (i.e. dust, water vapour, smog, etc.) can be determined by subtracting the Rayleigh optical density, along with small amounts of atmospheric absorption, from the total optical density. This resulting quantity is called the aerosol optical depth (AOD). As the name implies, this quantity comes from the scatter and absorption due to particles larger than air molecules. These particles vary greatly in size, as well as index of refraction and other important optical properties. To simplify matters, a single particle size and composition was assumed in this analysis to represent the spatial distribution of this aerosol scattering. Non-absorbing particles were also assumed since the interest is in the amount of scattered light. This is a gross simplification, but since the objective here is to compare scatter differences due to spectral changes, choosing a particular distribution is not essential to demonstrating that wavelength dependency decreases with increasing aerosol content. While the absolute estimates of angle-dependent scatter would likely improve with a more detailed treatment of particle size, the effect on the ratio of different spectra is a much reduced, second-order effect. A similar simplification of using a single Mie scattering angular distribution was used by Garstang in his seminal paper on modeling artificial night-sky illumination.12

Further support for the appropriateness of this simplified particle size treatment is that experimental measurements of scattering distributions show smooth, featureless distributions likely due to the diversity of particle shapes.13 The tendency towards smoother, featureless distributions suggests that using simple spherical particle shapes is adequate for modeling, especially since it is impossible to specify the exact shapes and sizes of particles in natural or artificial samples. Therefore, it is highly unlikely that some specific type of particle shape or distribution of sizes is going to lead to different conclusions once the general shape of the scattering distribution is taken into account by particle size.

For this paper, the idea was to err on the side of more wavelength dependency, so a relatively small representative particle diameter of 0.3 µm was used for most of the calculations presented here. Figure 3 shows the relative Mie scattering distribution for four particle diameters covering the range of suspended particle sizes in the atmosphere14,15 calculated using an online Mie scattering calculator.16 From these distributions, the proportion scattered toward the ground can be determined for different elevation angles of skyward directed light. Figure 3
Mie scattering distributions for different particle diameters16

The wavelength dependency of the aerosol scatter was determined empirically from AOD measurements taken at three different wavelengths (412, 500 and 862 nm) and fitted to a kλ−n equation, as in the case of Rayleigh scatter, but the fitted exponent terms here are much smaller. For Alberta, Canada, the fitted equation is 0.0251λ−1.5, and for Ireland, the fitted equation is 0.0540λ−0.8. From these fitted equations it is evident that Ireland has roughly twice the aerosol optical depth of Alberta, Canada, and this must be due to an increase in larger particles such as water vapour because of the lower wavelength dependency. In both these locations, the exponent is considerably smaller than the Rayleigh exponent of roughly 4. For each location, the median of recorded AOD values taken over 1 year (2007) was used for calculations.

The proportion of light scattered back to the ground was calculated separately for small particles (air molecules) using the Rayleigh equation and for larger particles (aerosols) using Mie theory in 5° increments from zero° (light projected at the zenith) to 80° (10° above the horizon). For both scattering regimes the atmospheric depth was estimated as m1/cos θ, where m1 is the standard air mass of 1, to model the increasing atmospheric path length as the angle approaches the horizon. For each angle, scatter at each wavelength increment was calculated for each source from 380 to 780 nm. For Mie scattering, the proportion scattered back to earth was calculated from the scattering distribution (Figure 3) where the orientation of the distribution was aligned with the angle of the projected light. Essentially this involves a three dimensional rotation of the Mie scattering distribution.

To facilitate the calculation of downward scattered flux for different incident ray angles the scattering distribution needs to be expressed as a function of the zenith angle regardless of the incident ray direction. In the coordinate system for specifying the scattering distribution function, the polar angle is the direction of the incident light ray and the distribution, given by r, is symmetrical about this polar axis denoted by θr. (7)r=f(θr)
The following coordinate system remapping was applied to express the distribution in terms of the fixed zenith polar angle: (8)rz(θz,φz,α)=f(θ') where (9)θ'=acos(sinαsinθzcosϕz+cosαcosθz)

The incident ray direction measured from the zenith is α, and θz and ϕz are the polar and azimuthal angles of the sky coordinate system where the polar angle is measured relative to the zenith. θ' is the angle between the incident ray direction and the direction of interest in the zenith coordinate system. The above equation for θ' was calculated from the definition of the dot product of two vectors (10)θ'=acos(a→·b→‖a‖‖b‖) where a→=r(sinα,0,cosα), b→=r(sinθcosφ, sinθsinφ,cosθ).
After the remapping, the flux scattered downward to Earth, Φdown, is computed by the integral over the bottom 2π solid angle (11)Φdown=∫02π∫π/2πrz(θz,φz)sinθzdθzdφz
This downward flux can then be expressed as a fraction of the total scattered flux computed similarly over the entire 4π solid angle.

Since the Mie scattering distribution is predominately forward scatter, symmetrical about the line of travel, very little light is scattered back to Earth for angles near zenith, and the amount approaches 50% as the angle of projected light nears 90°. As the angle approaches 90°, however, this simple modelling of the atmosphere becomes inaccurate due to the excessive atmospheric depth and curvature of the Earth. Therefore, calculations were extended to only 80°. Only first-order scatter was considered. Garstang applied a correction for double scatter, but also neglected higher order scatter.12 Since double and higher-order scatter similarly affect both spectral distributions (only a 22% difference at most), the differential effect will cancel out to a large extent when taking the ratio of scatter amounts.

By integrating over wavelength and weighting by the luminous efficiency function, the proportion of light scattered back to Earth was calculated for each different spectrum as a function of the angle of emission into the sky. Finally, the ratio of backscattered light for the two different spectra was calculated for each angle of emission into the sky to evaluate change in sky glow due solely to spectral differences.

sec.title: 5. Results
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the amount of light scattered back to Earth as a function of the emission angle into the sky (0° is the zenith, 90° is the horizon) for two aerosol concentrations representing a cool continental climate (Bratt’s Lake, Canada) and a more humid, marine climate (Mace Head, Ireland). The Rayleigh scatter is the same for each because the same sea-level amount of molecular atmosphere is used for both. While both types of scatter increase for light emitted at large angles (close to the horizon), aerosol scattering increases much more rapidly, from negligible amounts at angles near zenith, to values approaching molecular scatter at large angles. For light projected straight up, large particle scatter contributes very little to sky glow because the scattering is mainly in the forward direction. As the angle increases, the forward scattering contributes more to sky glow because now small changes in angle direct it back to the ground. Figure 4
Scatter for LED source using an aerosol particle diameter of 0.3 µm and the median AOD for each location. Rayleigh scatter (dashed line) is the same for both locations

Figure 5 shows how the fraction of light scattered back towards the Earth changes for different aerosol size assumptions. Very small particles have a much more symmetrical scattering distribution; so much more of the scattered light is directed back to Earth for all angles of emission. For large particles, scatter back towards Earth only becomes appreciable at large angles. Figure 5
Aerosol Mie scatter shown as the fraction of light scattered back to Earth as a function of the angle at which it is projected into the sky for different aerosol particle sizes. Calculations for these curves used the LED spectrum and the median AOD from Mace Head, Ireland

Figure 6 is a plot of the ratio of light scattered back to Earth for the LED source over that for the HPS source for Bratt’s Lake, Canada and Mace Head, Ireland for a median level of AOD. A high aerosol content representing the 90th percentile for Mace Head, Ireland is shown for comparison. Higher atmospheric aerosol content reduces the ratio of scattered light for all angles. The spectral difference falls to almost half of that for Rayleigh-only scattering for light directed at large angles measured from zenith. Figure 6
Ratio of light scattered back to Earth for the LED source over that for the HPS source for Bratt’s Lake, Canada (solid) and Mace Head, Ireland (dashed), for a median level of AOD, and for the 90th percentile of AOD from Mace Head, Ireland (dotted). All curves correspond to a 0.3 µm aerosol particle diameter

sec.title: 6. Discussion
sec.p: Despite the deep blue appearance of a clear sky, the increase in scattered light for a 6500 K LED source over that for a HPS source considering only molecular Rayleigh scattering is at most 22%. The key to reconciling why Rayleigh scatter can produce a deep blue sky, yet so modest a change in backscattered light for such differing spectra, is appreciating that the luminous efficiency functions that define the weighting function for calculating light from a spectral power distribution are relatively narrow compared to the entire visible spectrum. Both the photopic and scotopic luminous efficiency functions have a full-width half-maximum of approximately 100 nm, so even though the ratio of scattered light at 400 nm to that at 700 nm is 9.8 for Rayleigh scattering, the photopic weighting factor is very low at these extremes. In addition, very little power is radiated at these extremes for either spectrum.

Scattered light might appear more prominent for short wavelength-rich sources due to the changing spectral sensitivity of the eye between high and low light levels (Purkinje shift); however, this has less to do with increased scatter than with the characteristics of vision. While dark adaptation can certainly make scatter from some sources more noticeable than that from others, the choice of which luminous efficiency to use for evaluating scatter is a separate issue. (It is important to note that for foveal viewing, the spectral response of the eye remains photopic even in the dark.) Of course a 6500 K light source will have more scotopically-weighted scatter than a HPS source when compared at the same photopic levels, because the 6500 K source has more scotopic light. However, specifying light levels on equal scotopic content eliminates most of the difference; the LED and HPS scatter ratio is 1.20 for scotopic weighting (a 0.2 stellar magnitude change). The same argument holds for circadian system sensitivity and a melanopsin-weighting function17 results in a 1.11 increase for LED over HPS.

It is important to emphasise that the above ratios are for Rayleigh scattering only, which is an unrealistic, worst-case scenario for investigating spectral differences in scatter. As measurements show, aerosol scattering is much less wavelength dependent, and including it reduces the difference between LED and HPS sources by up to half. Aerosol scattering is most prevalent in and around urban and coastal areas, where most of the world’s population resides and where there is the most light at night.

Further decreasing the spectral scattering difference is the predominately large angle distribution of light up into the sky from luminaires. As shown in Figure 6, the ratio of scatter drops nearly in half for light emitted at angles near the horizon. While this argument considers only the direct component of light emitted into the sky, it has been reported1 that the spectral reflectance of different pavement types all decrease with decreasing wavelength (an average reduction of 35% from 650 to 450 nm) which would reduce the spectral scattering ratio for ground reflected light.

Computer programs have been developed that offer much more sophisticated scattering models than the one presented here for predicting sky illumination from man-made light sources.17,18 These models have the capability to predict sky glow for individual wavelengths; however, predictions comparing specific light sources are not reported. Importantly, the calculations presented here do not attempt to predict the actual amount of sky glow for any specific location or set of conditions as do these more sophisticated computer programs. The calculations presented here merely set an upper limit on ratio of scatter for different spectra and demonstrate how the actual differences in scattered light for different spectra are typically much lower due to the characteristics of aerosol scatter.

The main point of this paper is to put into perspective the change in sky glow that can be expected from a change in the spectrum of the light sources commonly used for outdoor lighting separated from all the other changes, good and bad, that accompany a change in technology. Society will need to decide whether the benefits of higher CCT white light sources, such as higher efficacy and increased brightness perception, outweigh the negatives, such as increased sky glow and the potential for greater circadian disruption. Isolating the comparison here to just spectral differences helps one weigh the options and choose or design the best product. It’s important to note that low CCT LEDs are available and can be specified; therefore, it is incorrect to imply that categorically LEDs produce more sky glow. On the contrary, more precise optical control in LED fixtures could lead to less upward-directed light than from traditional sources. Moreover, better power control options for LED systems (i.e. no restrike times, dimming capability, and instant-on) could lead to an overall decrease in sky glow because the fixtures would not need to be powered at 100% all night long. Hopefully the calculations presented here can help communities make informed decisions when considering the benefits and harms of outdoor lighting.
